title: What is Echinacea?: Immune Benefits and More
author: Deirdre Bell
description: Aside from the common cold, echinacea is also used topically for other reasons—such as to heal wounds and to treat dry, itchy skin.

Also known as black sampson, purple coneflower, rudbeckia, or sampson root, echinacea is one of the most widely used herbal supplements sold in the United States today. ( [5](https://www.aafp.org/afp/2003/0101/p77.html#afp20030101p77-b1)) Aside from its immune benefits, echinacea is also used topically for treating wounds and dry, itchy skin. ( [6](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/echinacea/ataglance.htm)) Types and forms of echinacea A popular herbal supplement, echinacea is derived from a North American flowering plant. Echinacea is available in several different forms, including tinctures, teas, capsules, tablets, and topical creams. Some supplements use the root of the plant, while others use the above-ground parts, including the flowers. ( [2](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12808356)) It's important to note that not all echinacea is created equal. In fact, "echinacea" is a broad term that refers to several different species of plants. Some of the most commonly available and thoroughly researched species include With several species and supplement forms of echinacea available, it can be difficult to interpret the existing research. Let's take a look at what the current research tells us about the health benefits of echinacea. Echinacea for the common cold When cold and flu season begins, you may hear about building your resilience with echinacea. Echinacea had been traditionally used in the United States and Europe for the treatment of the common cold. ( [2](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12808356)) However, research findings of studies examining the use of echinacea for colds and upper respiratory infections is mixed. For example, an analysis of 24 studies on the use of echinacea for the common cold concluded that there's no evidence to broadly recommend using echinacea for treating the common cold. Researchers did, however, find that taking echinacea to prevent colds may be effective. ( [3](https://www.cochranelibrary.com/cdsr/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD000530.pub3/full?highlightAbstract=withdrawn%7Cechinacea%7Cechinace)) This review, which included data from studies that used different species of echinacea, different parts of the plant, and varying dosages, concluded as a result that certain types of supplements may be more effective than others. ( [3](https://www.cochranelibrary.com/cdsr/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD000530.pub3/full?highlightAbstract=withdrawn%7Cechinacea%7Cechinace)) [8](https://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(07)70160-3/fulltext)) In this review, researchers concluded that echinacea lowered the odds of catching a cold by 58%. Echinacea administration also decreased the duration of a cold by one to four days. It's important to note that this analysis looked at different forms of the echinacea herb, making it difficult to determine the effectiveness of specific forms. ( [8](https://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(07)70160-3/fulltext)) Another meta-analysis concluded that echinacea extract may lower the risk of recurrent respiratory infections and reduce complications associated with respiratory infection, such as pneumonia, ear infections, and tonsillitis. ( [7](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25784510/)) Echinacea for wound healing When you have a skin wound, your body's first step in the healing process is to trigger the inflammatory response. However, if you're under [stress](https://fullscript.com/blog/supplements-to-manage-stress), your immune system can delay that response. Since echinacea is used to modulate the immune system, it has been suggested as a way to accelerate wound healing. [9](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2763438/)) Other research has found that Echinacea purpurea, when used in combination with two additional Gotu Kola (Centella asiatica) and elderberry (Sambucus nigra, may help to heal a wound when applied directly to the skin. In one animal study, a skin patch containing Echinacea purpurea, Gotu Kola, and elderberry was shown to improve surgical wound healing more effectively than similar patches that did not contain herbs. ( [1](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5024077/)) It's important to note that since echinacea was combined with other herbs in this study, it can not be concluded that the beneficial effects are attributed to echinacea alone. Echinacea for itchy skin Itchy [skin](https://fullscript.com/blog/healthy-skin-natural-supplements-and-vitamins), whether it's a result of eczema, dermatitis, or just plain dryness, can be quite uncomfortable. It's possible that a topical treatment containing Echinacea purpurea root extract could help put an end to the itch. In one study, researchers found that adults with itchiness either on the body or on the scalp found using emulsions or shampoo containing echinacea significantly relieved dryness and itchiness. ( [4](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6251459/)) If you suffer from itchy skin or scalp, it might be worth giving an echinacea cream or shampoo a try. Echinacea safety In general, echinacea is considered safe over a short period over time. Research hasn't yet determined whether there are any risks of long-term use. ( [6](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/echinacea/ataglance.htm)) Some people experience nausea or stomach ache when taking echinacea. Be sure to take it with food or a full glass of water to make it easier on your stomach. ( [6](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/echinacea/ataglance.htm)) Allergic reactions to echinacea are rarely reported. ( [6](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/echinacea/ataglance.htm)) We recommend that you always talk to your integrative healthcare practitioner before taking echinacea, or if you're pregnant or breastfeeding. It's also a good idea to talk to your practitioner or pharmacist about how echinacea might interact with any other medications or supplements you're taking. The bottom line In spite of the many variables surrounding types, plant parts, and forms of echinacea supplements available, it remains a very popular supplement for modulating the immune system, improving wound healing, and treating skin conditions. While the evidence remains inconclusive, the herb has been used for centuries with very few negative reactions reported. If you're looking to boost your immunity to ward off colds and upper respiratory infections, or if you suffer from itchy skin or poor wound healing, echinacea may be helpful. If you're a patient, speak to your integrative healthcare provider about incorporating echinacea into your wellness plan.
